projects.description: Here I'm using the React library to create an interactive photo gallery.  There are navigation buttons and a search bar that fetch data from the Flickr API and the app displays the images accordingly.

I used React to make this simple chrome extension that tells you the current time in three US time zones, including taking into account daylight saving time.  Since I'm currently in Australia and I have friends and family spread across the US, this serves as a quick reference instead of mental time conversion.

Object Oriented JavaScript in action. This is a browser-based word guessing game. The user guesses letters of a random, hidden phrase.  They win if they guess all of the letters in the phrase before they make five wrong guesses.

This project uses AJAX to create a fictional employee directory by communicating with a third-party API (Random People Generator).  It creates modal windows when you click on a user for more detail, and adds 'next' and 'prev' buttons to navigate within the modals.  There is also a simple search function for a better user interface.
A little meta, I know.  But this project is a great display of my Node and Express skills, as well as my familiarity with templating languages (in this case Pug).

This is an interactive form for a fictional tech conference.  It uses validation for name, email and credit card info, the select menus populate based on previous choices, and the total cost tallies as the user selects events to attend.  The end result is a more engaging and user friendly form.

This project uses pagination to improve the user experience of a webpage with a long list of data.  It provides navigation for clicking through small groups of the larger list, reducing clutter and improving readability.
